RMP Executive Summary

 

This Executive Summary briefly reviews the major elements of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the NuGen Energy, LLC (NuGen) ethanol production facility located near the city of Marion, Turner County, South Dakota, which began operation in 2008. This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. NuGen is subject to the RMP rule due to the onsite storage of natural gasoline (denaturant), a regulated flammable mixture, above the threshold quantity. NuGen previously stored anhydrous ammonia onsite above threshold levels, however, the storage tank has been de-inventoried and all anhydrous ammonia was removed from the process.



1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



NuGen is committed to protecting the environment and operating the facility in a manner that promotes the safety of employees and the general public. Management has adopted and implemented policies that adhere to applicable federal and state rules and regulations, and as such, the design and construction of NuGen has incorporated physical and operational safeguards to prevent accidental releases. Through the proper design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the equipment and the training of personnel, NuGen has minimized the hazard to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous materials.



In the event of a release, the NuGen's emergency response is described in its Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) and Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP), which consists of a Facility Response Plan (FRP) and Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures (SPCC) Plan. The ICP and ERAP consist of procedures for responding to releases, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is acci

dentally released. The procedures address emergency response (including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures), evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, NuGen has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions on the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training on performing their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to NuGen processes or emergency response procedures.



2.    Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled



NuGen is a corn-based denatured ethanol fuel production plant which operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week. Ethanol is produced through the conversion of corn starch to sugars and then conversion of the sugars to ethanol (i.e., grain alcohol) through a batch fermentation and continuous distillation process.



The RMP regulated material stored at NuGen is natural gasoline which is used as a denaturant in the ethanol fuel product.



3.    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



NuGen has programs in place to address accidental release prevention measures required by EPA, Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and notification requirements of EPA's Emergency Response and Community Right-to-Know (EPCRA) regulations. NuGen complies with the RMP for the management of regulated substances onsite such as denaturant (natural gasoline).



Employee Participation



NuGen encourages employees to participate in safety management and accident prevention. NuGen has developed an employee participation program as part of the RMP program. Process safety information, process hazar

d analysis (PHA) results, recommendations, and action items, incident investigations, compliance audits, operating procedures, emergency response plan, and records of management of change are available to the operating personnel.



Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information



NuGen utilizes the Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) PHA methodology. The PHA identified the following potential major hazards: fire, explosion, contamination, and tornados. NuGen utilizes process controls such as relief valves, check valves, interlocks, and grounding equipment to prevent or limit releases. NuGen also utilizes dike containment around the site's storage tanks, including the denaturant storage tank, to contain and mitigate liquid releases.

NuGen keeps a variety of technical documents onsite that are used to help maintain safe operation of the production process and provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, and piping & instrument drawings.



Operating Procedures and Training



NuGen is responsible for developing and implementing written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the RMP. The operating procedures were developed as a guide for those involved with initial start-up, normal operation, normal shutdown, and emergency shutdown of the process. NuGen developed and implemented a comprehensive training program for employees involved in facility operations. 



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews



As part of the management of change (MOC) process, whenever a modification to the existing process is planned, either temporary or permanent, NuGen requires a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR). The PSSR confirms that, prior to putting into service, the construction and equipment being used is in accordance with design speci

fications. The PSSR also confirms that the safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate training for each involved employee has been completed. A PSSR includes field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention measures are properly implemented.



Safe Work Practices



NuGen has safe work practices in place to ensure worker and process safety. These safety standards control entry into work areas and confined spaces, specify procedures to follow for isolating energy sources by lockout/tag-out, and describe the permitting process for completing work at NuGen. Safety standards and work procedures are reviewed annually.

 

Hot Work Permit



NuGen has a hot work permit program that details areas which require a permit and those areas for which a permit is not required. A hot work permit is required in process areas for cutting, welding, spark-producing equipment, etc., except in designated areas. The procedure includes accountability and responsibility for authorizing and issuing the hot work permit, display of the permit at the site of the hot work until the work is completed, site inspection, designation of appropriate precautions to be taken with the hot work, and assignment of a fire watch where appropriate.



Management of Change



NuGen's MOC program reviews proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials, and design conditions prior to implementation of the change. Changes are reviewed by an interdisciplinary team to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a process change.



Incident Investigation



NuGen has procedures to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of a regulated substance, fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental damage, or pe

rsonal injury. The procedure establishes the minimum guidelines and activities of the incident investigation program in order to reduce the likelihood of repetitive occurrences of events which could reasonably lead to catastrophic releases. Investigations will be undertaken by a team to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar release in the future. Corrective actions are tracked until they are completed. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years.



Compliance Audits



NuGen regularly conducts audits of the provisions of RMP and PSM to verify that procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed. A compliance audit of each program is conducted every three years. The audits include but are not limited to a review of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel. The audit team develops findings that are included in an audit report and forwarded to facility management for resolution. Findings and corrective actions taken in response to each finding are tracked until completion.



Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The processes at NuGen include hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The RMP Program elements, that were previously summarized, apply to the denaturant processes. Collectively, these program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors. In addition to RMP, the facility has instrumentation and equipment to detect, contain, and reduce the consequences of a release, including:



Release Detection 



-    Monitoring equipment to detect flow and tank liquid level changes

-    Video cameras are used to monitor the facility, including the storage tank area

-    Facility personnel conduct routine rounds through storage tank areas

-    Atmospheric relief devices

-    Check valves to prevent back flow of liquid

-    Safety interlocks

-    Grounding equipment to prevent electric discharges through the tank



 Release Mitigation 



-    Secondary containment to contain liquid releases

-    Fire suppression and extinguishing systems

-    Trained emergency response personnel

-    Emergency response equipment located onsite

-    Facility personnel respond to small spills onsite



4.      Accident History



The facility has not had any RMP-reportable accidents within the past five years.



5.    Emergency Response Program



As discussed above, NuGen maintains a written ICP and ERAP at the facility. The purpose of these documents is to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. These documents address aspects of emergency response, step-by-step emergency situation assessments, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident requirements. In addition, NuGen has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures according to their role at the site, so that they are prepared and capable to respond up to incipient level fires or spills incident potentials. NuGen works with the local fire department and emergency responders to ensure the proper execution of the site plans. The emergency response program will be updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.



6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



NuGen has been designed and constructed to meet existing construction and process safety requirements. NuGen continually reviews safety practices and equipment, and maintenance programs are monitored on an ongoing basis. In an effort to improve site safety, NuGen has finalized efforts to de-in
ventory the remaining ammonia and has decommissioned the system, as mentioned above. NuGen is planning to remove the decommissioned ammonia tank from the site.
